thread.title: East Africa: Kenya, Uganda to Float Tenders for Pipeline
thread.title_full: East Africa: Kenya, Uganda to Float Tenders for Pipeline

title: East Africa: Kenya, Uganda to Float Tenders for Pipeline
text:
Kenya: New Kenyan Law to Regulate Oil, Gas Exploration 
The Hoima-Lamu crude oil pipeline is expected be completed either in 2018 or 2019, as the project has been integrated into the Lamu Port- South Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor (Lapsset) infrastructure project. 
The Lapsset Corridor Development Authority (LCDA) said a tender inviting companies to submit bids to build the crude oil pipeline will be floated before the end of this year to pave the way for construction work to start in 2016. 
LCDA director-general Silvester Kasuku said construction of the pipeline will be funded through debt and equity, but the ratios will be decided after a transaction advisor has been selected. 
"The selection of a transaction advisor is almost complete. The first oil is expected to flow in 2019. The pipeline is a critical success factor of Lapsset, which will open 70 per cent of Kenya's landmass to economic development," he said. 
Project components include the Lamu port, a standard gauge railway, roads, refined products pipeline, airports, resort cities and a crude oil refinery in Lamu. East Africa
